title: Cat. 113.2  Two Women Chattering, 1900
publication_title: Gauguin Paintings, Sculpture, and Graphic Works at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Two Women Chattering, headpiece for Le sourire (The Smile)  
1900  
Only state  
Wood-block print in black ink on thin ivory laid Japanese paper; 102 × 151mm (image); 151 × 229 mm (sheet)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, Clarence Buckingham Collection, 1951.38  
Guérin 81, Kornfeld 62 C  
For the verso, see fig. 113.2.1

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section technical_report" id="technical_report">Gauguin carved interchangeable vignettes and headpieces to accompany the text of his self-published journal, Le sourire (The Smile). He used a small piece of coarsely grained wood to carve this image, in contrast to the fine-grained boxwood used for Three People, a Mask, a Fox, and a Bird (cat. 111) and Fox, Busts of Two Women, and a Rabbit (cat. 120). As in theSuite of Late Wood-Block Prints (cats. 91–105), this piece of wood likely derived from an indigenous source that the artist prepared for carving and printing himself.

This headpiece was used to adorn two issues of Le sourire; better known is its inclusion in the January 1900 issue (fig. 113.2.2). Gauguin also pasted an impression into a manuscript of Le sourire that he sent to Georges-Daniel de Monfreid in which he combined the text from the November and January issues (fig. 113.2.3). The block is extant, in the collection of the Národní Galerie, Prague (fig. 113.2.4).

This impression is printed in black ink.

The thin sheet of mitsumata (est.) paper presents a delicate laid and chain line pattern. There are small fibrous clumps and inclusions throughout. It is an absorbent Japanese paper that took the ink readily from the block, resulting in a soft, rich impression. The sheet is scissor scut along all edges. In order to successfully print such a thin sheet, a more substantial secondary paper was likely used as a carrier to help facilitate lifting the mitsumata paper from the inked block. The sheets of delicate Japanese paper were printed individually, rather than as a group of two or three on a larger sheet, given their fragility and the skill required to lift them from the wood block.

Gauguin adhered an impression of this print to page 186 of his Noa Noa, Voyage de Tahiti, along with impression of At The Black Rocks (cat. 91) and Bust of Nude Womanand Three-Quarter Figure of a Man with a White Cap in Profile, Third Small Figure at Far Right (cat. 121) (fig. 113.2.5). This suggests that these held particular significance for him; in addition, the vertical stacking of three images may well point to the artist’s method of printing blocks consecutively as a group of two or three on larger sheets of Western paper (see Oviri [cat. 84.1, fig. 84.1.3]).

102 × 151mm (image); 151 × 229 mm (sheet)

Conservation documentation indicates that the sheet was humidified and flattened in September 1984.

The print is in sound, stable condition. There are small losses in the top corners of the sheet.  
Mary Broadway and Harriet K. Stratis

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section provenance" id="provenance">Sold by Robert G. Michel, Paris, to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1951.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section references" id="references">Elizabeth Mongan, Eberhard W. Kornfeld, and Harold Joachim, Paul Gauguin: Catalogue Raisonné of His Prints, with assistance of Christine H. Stauffer (Galerie Kornfeld, 1988), pp. 230–31, cat. 62 (ill.).

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section other_documentation" id="other_documentation">Inscribed in wood block, along left side, printed in white-line manner: LE SOURIRE

The nature of the media and their application, as well as the condition of the artwork, were assessed through visual examination using normal, transmitted, and raking light; microscope magnification (80–300×); and ultraviolet-light examination (254 and 365 nm).

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">The catalogue raisonné erroneously listed this as 62 C, a posthumous impression, when in fact it should have been listed as 62 A, a trial proof. See Elizabeth Mongan, Eberhard W. Kornfeld, and Harold Joachim, Paul Gauguin: Catalogue Raisonné of His Prints, with assistance of Christine H. Stauffer (Galerie Kornfeld, 1988), p. 230, cat. 62.

The catalogue raisonné erroneously listed this as 62 C, a posthumous impression, when in fact it should have been listed as 62 A, a trial proof. See Elizabeth Mongan, Eberhard W. Kornfeld, and Harold Joachim, Paul Gauguin: Catalogue Raisonné of His Prints, with assistance of Christine H. Stauffer (Galerie Kornfeld, 1988), p. 230, cat. 62.

Libuŝe Sýkorová, Gauguin Woodcuts, trans. Till Gottheiner (P. Hamlyn, 1963), cat. 7.

Fiber analysis was conducted on Tahitian Carrying Bananas (), and mitsumata fiber was confirmed. IPS Testing, Appleton, Wisc., report no. IPS 00592-15, conservation object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago. Although Tahitian Carrying Bananas was the only print that was sampled and analyzed, visual examination of the Suite of Late Wood-Block Prints (cats. 91–105) and various prints for Le sourire revealed that these works were also printed on the same type of paper. The appearance, tone, surface quality, weight, and even fiber distribution found in these papers are identical.

Catherine Maynor, treatment report and photographic documentation, Sept. 1984, conservation object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago.

</section><section id="figures">Cat. 113.2 Two Women Chattering, headpiece for Le sourire (The Smile), 1900.

fig. 113.2.2 The complete folio of Gauguin’s Le sourire: Journal méchant (Jan. 1900) with the headpiece Two Women Chattering. From Paul Gauguin, “Le sourire” de Paul Gauguin, facsimile ed. (G.-P. Maisonneuve, 1952).

fig. 113.2.3 An impression of Two Women Chattering and text from the November 1899 and January 1900 issues of Gauguin’s Le sourire, from an autograph manuscript and cyclostyle. Houghton Library, Harvard University, MS Typ 611-611.1.

fig. 113.2.4 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Wood block for Two Women Chattering. Wood block. Národní Galerie, Prague.

fig. 113.2.5 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Impression of Two Women Chattering, pasted onto fol. 97R, top, of the bound manuscript Noa Noa, Voyage de Tahiti, 1893–1901. Musée d’Orsay, Paris, given by Georges-Daniel de Monfreid, 1927, RF 7259.53.

fig. 113.2.1 Verso of Gauguin’s Two Women Chattering, headpiece for Le sourire (The Smile) (1900). The Art Institute of Chicago, 1951.38.

</section>
